Award.AwardTitle: COLLABORATIVE RESEARCH/WORKSHOP: Behavioral Models of Politics

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Social, Behav & Economic Scie

Division.LongName: Divn Of Social and Economic Sciences

Award.AbstractNarration:
General Summary

This project advances the science of behavioral models of politics through a workshop, training, and research. Theoretical models of political processes are essential tools that help structure our understanding of power, conflict, democracy, and institutions. Models challenge intuitions, clarify the logic of explanations, and guide empirical inquiry regarding diverse topics spanning the traditional subfields of political science: elections, collective action, war and conflict, trade, and identity formation, to name a few. Current approaches to theoretical modeling in political science are dominated by rational choice and game theory, having borrowed heavily from a rigorous mathematical tradition in economics. Advances in psychology and economics, however, show the limits of the standard approach's model of rational human decision-making. By incorporating behavioral insights into theoretical models, the field of behavioral models of politics broadens the theoretical methodologies available to political scientists. The workshop advances this new field by bringing together an interdisciplinary group of scholars with a shared interest in understanding bounded rationality and its implications for political behavior, training junior scholars, promoting vigorous scientific dialogue, identifying new research priorities, and stimulating new research collaborations and synergies.

Technical Summary

This project advances the science of behavioral models of politics through a workshop, training, and research. Theoretical models of political processes are essential tools that help structure the understanding of power, conflict, democracy, and institutions. The workshop advances this new field by bringing together an interdisciplinary group of scholars with a shared interest in understanding bounded rationality and its implications for political behavior, training junior scholars, promoting vigorous scientific dialogue, identifying new research priorities, and stimulating new research collaborations and synergies. The workshop facilitates the promotion of communication and the exchange of ideas across field and disciplinary boundaries. It will result in productive collaboration between and coordination among scientists. Workshop presentations will be structured and organized as part of a series of "modeling dialogues" that pair theoretical and experimental research that addresses the same substantive topics. Additionally, the workshop will include a training workshop and mentoring activities. Participants to the workshop are obtained through a general call. In addition, PIs use established networks to draw in members of underrepresented groups in modeling politics.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Formal theories of political processes help structure our understanding of the political world. They clarify and challenge intuitions regarding diverse topics spanning the traditional subfields of political science: elections, collective action, war and conflict, trade, and identity formation, to name a few. Yet, this breadth is not mirrored in the set of approaches formal theorists use, which has been dominated for decades by a rational choice approach. While the benefits of this consistent approach have been manifold, a broad, interdisciplinary, and growing literature illustrates its limitations, and suggests new avenues of research. The behavioral approach to formal political science, pioneered by such giants as Herbert Simon and Elinor Ostrom, takes into account evidence from across the behavioral sciences in developing theories that provide more accurate representations of human behavior and that often produce very different predictions about political outcomes.

Though these behavioral approaches have also been around for decades, only now are they beginning to see greater use. This is due, in large part, to advances in related disciplines such as cognitive psychology and behavioral economics, from which political scientists borrow heavily and where decision-making and rationality are also central concerns. By running carefully controlled experiments, social scientists have been able to learn numerous things that belie standard rational choice and game theoretic assumptions, such as preference reversals, errors in probability judgments and Bayesian updating, limits to iterated reasoning and backward induction, and failure of common knowledge of rationality. It is time for behavioral insights to be incorporated into the models political scientists employ, broadening the theoretical methodologies available to political scientists—not only to provide a richer picture of the political world but also to ensure vigorous competition in the marketplace of ideas.

The Behavioral Models of Politics Workshop at the University of Pittsburgh promoted the development and advancement of the science of behavioral models of politics. Participants explored ways in which boundedly rational behavior can be modeled and applied to better understand political attitudes, processes, and institutions. The project brought together an interdisciplinary group of scholars with a shared interest in understanding bounded rationality and its implications for political behavior, thereby promoting a vigorous scientific dialogue between theorists, experimentalists, and other scientists.

Intellectual Merit: The proposal brought together scholars across disciplinary lines, with the resulting dialogue encouraging theorists to develop and identify tractable formal models of bounded rationality in political settings while also stimulating experimentalists to test such models and identify key empirical regularities that should be incorporated into new models. In addition to broadening individual scholars’ research, the promotion of communication and the exchange of ideas across field and disciplinary boundaries furthered the productive collaboration between and coordination among scientists. The diverse community of scientists brought together by the proposal promotes and accelerates the growth of a very new area of research and aids in developing urgent research priorities and in fostering consensus about the most promising methodologies.

Broader Impacts: The project provided exposure to and training in behavioral methods and research for participants. This fostered greater familiarity of theoretical and empirical behavioral approaches among participants, as well as allowed participants to incorporate what they learned into their home institutions via teaching at all levels. Continued dissemination of behavioral approaches is expected given the interdisciplinary nature of the workshop and the wide range of topics within political science and beyond to which behavioral approaches may be fruitfully applied.

The conference program, list of participants, and papers presented can be found at: https://sites.google.com/site/behavioralmodels2016/
